replies.body: The First Amendment (free speech) only applies to government law, not social policy within a game. There are standards which you agree to meet when you accept the Terms of Use; if you do not accept these terms you aren't allowed to play the game, so don't sign it if you don't agree.

She's right, you're wrong.

League of Legends is property of Riot Games, and they can run it as they please. The rules require players to conduct themselves in a sportsmanlike manner, and every player agrees to these rules before they begin playing.
How is your comment relevant? Or are you just attempting to change the subject because you don't have an argument?

Nami is correct regarding the application of the first amendment. 

If you walk into my home spewing racial slurs at me or my guests and tell us a bigoted and hateful opinion of us, I have every right to kick you out of my home. I can enforce whatever speech restricting rules I want in my home. Private entities have different rules than the government. On my private property, you are a guest and must follow my rules. 

Another example is like going to an amusement park. The public can obtain a ticket and enter. The public is there but you break their rules, the amusement park can kick you out.

Do not be confused with "accessible to the public" with "public property." Riot is allowing their property to be accessible to the public however they can escort you off their property if you break their rules.

League of Legends is Riot's home, Riot's private property. Riot can enforce whatever speech restricting rules in their own home, their private property. Your ticket to enter is agreeing to their TOS and EULA. You break any rules in the TOS or EULA, they can revoke your entry and remove you, ie ban you.

Some behavior just crosses the line and warrants more than a chat restriction. These things tend to not be ok anywhere; typically hate speech and threats or urging someone to harm themselves or others.

If you post the logs we'd be happy to go over them with you if you aren't sure why your punishment was escalated to a ban. If you want to speak to player support about it you can submit a [Support Ticket](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/requests/new).

I do it to help people. Some people have questions they legitimately don't know the answer to regarding their punishments or what is and is not acceptable, among other things. This is the first or second place most people turn to for those answers, and since I have the ability to post information here it is one of the most effective ways to provide those answers. It provides me with some idle entertainment.

You don't see me as much as Nami or Aero for example though because I prefer not to answer stuff that already has an answer unless I feel it was not answered fully or they had additional questions, and I don't check the boards as often throughout the day as they do.

Riot has the right to take away certain speech in their game. And punish you for it. It's not illegal since you can still say it, you just can be punished for it.

Look at it like this. You do not get hurt, by being unable to say your offensive opinion. Other people do get hurt because said opinion is offensive. 

The system is built upon the playerbase and adheres largely to what we define as right or wrong. Free speech has nothing to do with using homophobic slurs towards someone on the internet. It's there so the government can't silence you. 

By playing League you do not only accept to play adhering to Riots rules, but also to the community, since said rules are ammended by Riot to adhere with what the community wants.

You haven't shown your chat log so no one can tell how bad your comments were, but Riot and the community has very low tolerance for racist, sexist, homophobic, bigoted and or otherwise hateful speech.

So if your comments fall under those kinds of speech and it was systematic and continuous for the sake of harassing a person in a game, it may be that your behavior elevated past chat bans to show you that your behavior was at an unacceptable level.

Take this for example:

You never have given a dirty look to anyone in your life before. You see someone and you give them a dirty look. Doesn't really elevate to getting arrested.

vs

You have never given a dirty look to anyone in your life before. You have never punched someone in the nose before. You go out and give someone a dirty look and punch someone in the face and break their nose. Just because you didn't punch anyone in the face before doesn't mean you get less of a punishment because it's the first nose you've broken. You went past the dirty look and elevated your offense to breaking a nose. So you're going to get punished for breaking a nose.
